title: 103_hr354
content: The Act titled "Expedited Consideration of Proposed Rescissions Act of 1993" amends the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974 to allow for expedited consideration of certain proposed rescissions. The "Expedited Consideration of Proposed Rescissions Act of 1993" allows the President to propose rescinding budget authority provided in an appropriations Act through a special message to Congress within 3 days of enactment. The proposed rescission cannot be repeated under this section or section 1012. The "Expedited Consideration of Proposed Rescissions Act of 1993" allows the President to propose rescinding budget authority within 3 days of enactment. The President must send a separate special message for each subcommittee of the Committee on Appropriations and specify the budget authority to be rescinded. The amount proposed for rescission for a program, project, or activity cannot exceed 25% of the appropriated amount. The "Expedited Consideration of Proposed Rescissions Act of 1993" allows the President to propose rescinding budget authority within 3 days of enactment. The proposed rescission for a program, project, or activity may not exceed 25% of the appropriated amount and must be authorized by law. Procedures for expedited consideration require the introduction of a draft bill or joint resolution within two days of receiving a special message from the President. On the third day after receiving a special message from the President, any Member of the House may introduce a bill or joint resolution. The bill will be referred to the Committee on Appropriations, which must report it within seven days. If the committee fails to do so, the bill will be automatically placed on the calendar. A bill or joint resolution introduced in the House must be voted on within 10 days of introduction. If passed, it is engrossed, certified, and transmitted to the Senate on the same day. A bill or joint resolution transmitted to the House or Senate must be referred to the Committee on Appropriations, which must report the bill without substantive revision within seven days. Failure to do so results in automatic discharge from consideration, and the bill is placed on the calendar for a vote on final passage. The House or Senate must refer a bill or joint resolution to the Committee on Appropriations, which must report it within seven days. If the bill is agreed to, it is returned to the originating House. A motion in the House to consider a bill under this section is highly privileged and not debatable. Amendments to the motion are not allowed. Debate on a bill or joint resolution in the House of Representatives under this section is limited to 4 hours, divided equally between supporters and opponents. Limiting further debate or moving to recommit the bill is not allowed. Appeals on the application of House rules to the bill's procedure can be made. Consideration of a bill or joint resolution under this section in the Senate is governed by the Rules of the House of Representatives. A motion to proceed to the bill's consideration is privileged and not debatable, with a 10-hour limit on debate and related motions. Debate in the Senate on any debatable motion or appeal in connection with a bill or joint resolution under this section shall be limited to not more than 1 hour, equally divided between the mover and the manager of the bill, with additional time allotted by the leaders if needed. The Senate can limit debate time on a bill or joint resolution to 1 hour. No amendments are allowed, and any budget authority proposed for rescission must be made available for obligation. The Senate can limit debate time on a bill or joint resolution to 1 hour without amendments. Any budget authority proposed for rescission must be available for obligation the day after the bill is defeated in either House of Congress. Definitions for "appropriation Act" and "continuity of a session" are provided in this section. Rulemaking powers under Section 904 of the Act are also amended. Section 904 of the Act is amended to include sections 1013 and 1018. Conforming amendments are made to sections 1011 and 1015, updating references to sections 1013 and 1018. The text chunk involves amending various subsections by updating references from sections 1012 and 1013 to include section 1014. Additionally, a new subparagraph (B) is added related to transmitting a special message. The text chunk involves amending section 1016 of the Act to include references to section 1014 and adding a new subparagraph related to transmitting a special message under section 1013. Section 1013 of the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974 expedites consideration of certain proposed rescissions. It applies to budget authority provided by appropriation Acts enacted during the One Hundred Third Congress and terminates when Congress adjourns sine die in 1994.
